Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Hydrazone-Based Switches - Simple Systems for Sophisticated Functions
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Dr. Ivan Aprahamian of Dartmouth College develops easy to make, modular and tunable hydrazone-based switches, and studies ways to integrate them into polymers and liquid crystals. This proposal offers a new strategy for the development of adaptive functional materials (such as chemically activated actuators, sensors and molecular machines) by using synthetically straightforward building blocks. It is expected that this approach will facilitate the structure-property analysis of the systems, which will enable the rapid production of i) molecular machines for nanotechnology applications, ii) stimuli-responsive polymers that can convert chemical energy into mechanical motion, and iii) pH sensitive liquid crystals that can be used as sensors for environmental pollutants.

The broader impacts of this research entail i) using the ACS SEED project and other endeavors to retain students of different levels (high school, undergraduate and graduate students) in the sciences, ii) piloting and assessing classroom technologies that can augment the learning experience of students, and iii) developing hands-on self-assembly demonstrations to educate the general public about important concepts related to supramolecular chemistry and nanotechnology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project "Hydrazone-Based Switches - Simple Systems for Sophisticated Functions" was focused on developing structurally simple hydrazone-based switches and using them in controlling reaction cascades and the properties of liquid crystals. Molecular switches (i.e., molecular triggers that change their properties/structure as a function of an external stimulus) are ubiquitous in nature and are involved, for example, in the first step of a complicated cascade of events that lead to vision. Moreover, such switches are used in day-to-day applications such as photochromic lenses.

In this project, we developed new reaction cascades that can mimic (to a limited extent) the multistep switching events found in biology. For example, we developed a synthetic negative feedback loop that can control the concentration of an analyte. We also showed how the coupling between light- and chemically-activated switches can address the long-standing issue of waste management in chemically-controlled switches. Moreover, we used the switches as sensors that can be used in detecting biogenic amines that are responsible for food poisoning. Finally, we developed a new family of bistable photochromic compounds that have promising properties and can be used in photochromic lenses, among other applications.  

The broader impact of this project lies in the better understanding of reaction cascades and how to control them to effect useful functions (e.g. control of analyte concentration). Moreover, a patent related to the new photochromic compounds was filed, as we expect these systems to be of commercial interest. Significantly, the most importnat impact of this grant was the training of high-school, undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral students, who came from a diverse pool of backgrounds, in supramolecular and materials chemistry. This training equipped the students for positions in industry, academia and even governmental positions. Moreover, this grant enabled us to interact with the general public through our numerous outreach events, which broadened the reach of the science we are conducting in the laboratory.
